awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T3: Advancing Technologies and Improving Communication of  Urine-Derived Fertilizers for Food Production within a Risk-Based Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
#1639244
Nancy G. Love

Nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) are nutrient fertilizers that are critically important for sustained food production.  In the US the vast majority of N and P enters cities in the form of food and leaves as emissions from wastewater treatment plants.  These emissions enter into the environment and can cause toxic algal blooms, excessive greenhouse gas emissions, and "dead zones". Recovering nutrients at an earlier point in the cycle and repurposing them as safe fertilizers to support food production will significantly reduce the energy required for fertilizer production and ensure a safe, domestic fertilizer source for generations.  This project focuses on applying proven treatment technologies in a new way to recover and repurpose nutrients from urine into fertilizer while reducing the risks associated with chemical or biological contaminants that exist in conventional fertilizers used today.  This approach reduces the number of steps between wastewater production and fertilizer capture. Because perceptions toward nutrient reuse from urine could be negative, the PIs include an educational program will educate the public about the science behind the approach. 

The vast majority of N and P consumption in human-dominated environments is derived from food.  Nutrients in food that are consumed by people ultimately end up in landfills or wastewater effluents. There is a critical need to recover these nutrients and redirect them to support food production in an energy efficient and environmentally favorable manner. This project will advance energy efficient N and P recovery in the US through demonstration and deployment of technologies that produce safe urine-derived fertilizers (UDFs) via urine diversion. The PIs will use a data-informed, risk-based approach to assess the safety of UDFs.  Field trials involving the growth of lettuce, carrots or hay will be conducted to determine the fate of biological (viruses, bacteria, antibiotic resistance genes) or chemical (heavy metals, trace organic) contaminants. The urine processing methods to be evaluated are a collection of technologies that have the capacity to efficiently achieve nutrient recovery, reduce fertilizer product volume, improve product aesthetics, and reduce undesirable contaminants. The PIs will extend UDF product generation through crop field trials and conduct a comprehensive monitoring campaign in support of a risk assessment. Because social attitudes toward using UDF for food may be negative, mainly due to a lack of information about risks relative to conventional methods, the PIs will integrate an assessment and communication program that involves surveys, focus groups and the development of educational materials to advance understanding about this approach. These methods are intended to advance public acceptance of urine-centered recycling technologies for sustainable food production and security.  Programs that will develop a higher level of public understanding about urine-centered nutrient recycling technologies include professional training (student summer internships), unique forums for student and public learning (development of case-based learning tools; a new course; and construction of a urine diversion and UDF-processing facility for application to non-food crop at the University of Michigan botanical gardens), and information dissemination (an annual Urine Diversion and Recycling Summit and themed sessions at national conferences).

por.por_cntn:
Human urine contributes most of the nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) in domestic wastewater. Our current approach to managing these nutrients in human waste is very inefficient: water resource recovery facilities (WRRFs, the treatment plants where wastewater is managed) only capture a fraction of NPK nutrients and most return to the environment in a reactive form (either in liquid discharges or in biosolids), where they are pollution. When NPK ends up in biosolids from WRRFs, they are present at a fixed NPK ratio and a dilute mass that restricts the flexibility of farmers who may choose to fertilize with these products.  To achieve nutrient efficiency and sustainability, it is best to recover and reuse these nutrients when they are most concentrated, which also enhances the efficiency of treatment processes to convert them into useful forms. Further, it is desirable to capture N, P, and K separately, if possible, so that desired ratios can be used by farmers only as needed.  The goal of this project was to (i) evaluate technologies that capture, concentrate, and remove contaminants from urine and turn it into useful N, P, and/or K fertilizer products, (ii) understand stakeholder perceptions around urine-derived fertilizers (UDFs) and build education and outreach programs based on those findings, and (iii) conduct a risk assessment of exposure to untreated contaminants (pharmaceuticals, pathogens). The broader impacts included exposing the public and students to the benefits of sustainable, regional fertilizer production through UDF through local (outreach at public events, internships), national (presentations at conferences focused on the water industry) and international (Rich Earth Summit and international conferences around distributed water systems) activities. Through this project, we demonstrated how UDF processing steps reduce or eliminate the risk of biological contaminants (bacteria, viruses, antibiotic resistance genes) from UDF products.  We demonstrated how to effectively conduct scientifically rigorous UDF field trial experiments that include use of advanced analytical chemistry methods to evaluate the fate of pharmaceuticals through soil and crops.  We developed a method to predict the fate of organics contained within urine during UDF treatment.  We assessed several technologies to concentrate and to decontaminate UDF.  One of those technologies (freeze concentration) received a patent as an outcome of this grant. We conducted a life cycle assessment of UDF as applied in three distinct regions of the U.S. (Virginia, Vermont, Michigan) while considering the regulations distinct to each region for managing nutrients.  That analysis showed that resource recovery by urine separation and processing has lower environmental impacts overall relative to conventional wastewater treatment. We also evaluated the risk of chemical exposure by consuming crops fertilized with UDF that was not treated for trace contaminant removal versus crops irrigated with pharmaceutical-containing reuse waters (a common practice in the U.S.). That evaluation showed that the risks between these two modes of exposure are not different for the case when UDF is not treated to remove the contaminants.  In fact, the risk associated with using UDF that had chemical contaminants removed is less. Finally, our team conducted multiple perception studies using different methods.  Through this, we learned how exposure to a small amount of educational material about UDF, biosolids, organic fertilizers, and conventional fertilizers helped potential consumers, farmers and regulators develop a better understanding of the true risks of chemical exposure or crop contamination across all fertilizer types. We created an educational video to convey the opportunities, benefits, and gaps around UDF (https://youtu.be/iX1F4dYLF84).  In summary, we advanced public understanding of UDF, developed technological approaches to creating safe UDF products, created methods for further analyzing UDF, and demonstrated through modeling the sustainability and level of manageable risk associated with use of properly treated UDF.
